The team continues to work to resolve any impact of the attrition. However, historically, as you can see from the time we've done price increases that there is some rationalization that occurs. I'll have Bryan to comment on what he customers.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Quite frankly, this was a key period for the introduction of that FD increase. And as John alluded to, the attrition rates are very stable. We didn't see any sizable shift based on what we experienced in the past, which is positive news to us. I think wha
componenttext: Quite frankly, this was a key period for the introduction of that FD increase. And as John alluded to, the attrition rates are very stable. We didn't see any sizable shift based on what we experienced in the past, which is positive news to us. I think what's very important to note is the effects of the orders that we have been conducting. In fact, what we are seeing is increase compliance. We're seeing more subscribers coming in to play as a result of those audits that were correcting wrong behavior, which is a positive. Also, another observation is significant increase, subscriber usage in the APAC region, which again, is another positive.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: First of all, as you know our international daily volume now is up 14% year-on-year to $4.4 million of our overall contract volume, it's very positive from our perspective. We've seen a 30% increase in activity in Asia were averaging close to 900,000 cont
componenttext: First of all, as you know our international daily volume now is up 14% year-on-year to $4.4 million of our overall contract volume, it's very positive from our perspective. We've seen a 30% increase in activity in Asia were averaging close to 900,000 contracts today coming out of Asia. We're getting about 3.4 million average EMEA. You know really, this has been a story of investment and focused activities in sales and marketing and having the people on the ground as we've represented in the past. You heard me speak about country specific planning and being able to target our focus across countries within each of these regions. Just to highlight our customers segment year-on-year growth throughout international was led by the asset managers, up 42%. Commercials were up 35%. Banks were up 23%. Retail, nice growth, up 23%. Our overall nonmember growth was up 60% year-on-year in international.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And Chris, let me just add to what Bryan said. You mentioned regulatory. We don't think that's always a sustainable way to look at a future growth. I will tell you that when there is regulatory uncertainties, people migrate to where the certainties at. Th
componenttext: And Chris, let me just add to what Bryan said. You mentioned regulatory. We don't think that's always a sustainable way to look at a future growth. I will tell you that when there is regulatory uncertainties, people migrate to where the certainties at. The United States is already being passed and implemented many years ago and people understanding where the rules are, whether they like it or not is different topic for discussion, but the point is, it's been done. And when you look at some of the European regions obviously, they're not there yet. So that regulatory uncertainty does breathe lesser volume there and that brings it here to the states.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: The other point I want to note is our focus on growing during the regional hours. This is the story that we've been telling all of you for many, many quarters now. During Q2 2018, we saw a 34% increase in our activity during European trading hours. 45% du
componenttext: The other point I want to note is our focus on growing during the regional hours. This is the story that we've been telling all of you for many, many quarters now. During Q2 2018, we saw a 34% increase in our activity during European trading hours. 45% during Asian trading hours. Now I know you have all the dependencies. If you look at the overall volume that is occurring during their regional hours, a substantial portion of these activities are occurring during the delay hours, very important. Typical story.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: Great. one quick follow-up question. Terry, you mentioned volumes have slowed in July. I do agree that somewhat seasonal. The one that's a little surprising is just the ag volume. It's weaker than one would expect. Curious if the tariffs and things like that and have any impact? Or maybe any color on your end as to why you think volumes are slow, really slow there?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Chris. It's Derek. We had a series of records over the course of the -- this year in Q2. We had a monthly record -- total volume record of open insurance record on contract or continue to push those directions. But we're also seeing is record large open i
componenttext: Chris. It's Derek. We had a series of records over the course of the -- this year in Q2. We had a monthly record -- total volume record of open insurance record on contract or continue to push those directions. But we're also seeing is record large open interest holders in our market, and what's important, tying back the question that Bryan just answered is our non-U.S. growth story with Trump announcing tariffs that were coming on board that has created a significant concern about price risk. That drove a lot of the volume into participation in our contracts. This is very much a risk on environment as represented by the record volume and record open interest and large open interest holders. We're also seeing on the day that we saw record volumes overall in the complex back in June. Most important, we saw record levels of participation from non-U.S. participants. So as regulatory concerns come on board relative to tariffs or not, we're actually seeing people pile in. For example, with the announcement yesterday. Trump and a meeting that had a very positive impact. We are seeing our ag volumes overnight roughly come in at twice the amount. As of 7 o'clock called this morning, we had about 220,000 contracts in our ag contracts. We typically see a slowdown going into the 7 months of Q3. We're coming from record highs in Q1 and Q2, and our ag volume has also set a record over the course of Q2. So we're seeing some seasonal basis of slowdown, but right now, as Terry mentioned before, starting from record levels and open interest and global participation. So we think will be good for the balance of the year should bring. We'll see immediate positive impact on our volumes based on the questions that have been results of our.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And I think the real story here is not so much on what the volumes are because as Derek said, we are the benchmark pricing mechanism for agriculture throughout the world. I think it's just the overall price that the impact on the regional farmers during t
componenttext: And I think the real story here is not so much on what the volumes are because as Derek said, we are the benchmark pricing mechanism for agriculture throughout the world. I think it's just the overall price that the impact on the regional farmers during the U.S. versus globally, so the difference between the prices and U.S. prices that's really where most of the stroy is being told, but I do think that will be ironed out. Hence, when you saw what Derek just referenced with the conversations between Europe and the U.S. will unfold, I'm hopeful for the U.S. environment that it will go the same way with Asia.

And then, Maybe you could talk about that net rate earned after the June hikes. So the 3Q earning rate. And then just a clarification on the market date. I think you guys raised the pricing on April 15, if I'm correct on that. And to what extent audit fees impacted that market date number in Q2?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thank you, Bryan. I'll walk you through the accounts and what occurred this quarter. Then, I'll hit the market date question. So in terms of the impact on the fed accounts or amounts for managing cash. In the first quarter, we had average cash balan
componenttext: Sure. Thank you, Bryan. I'll walk you through the accounts and what occurred this quarter. Then, I'll hit the market date question. So in terms of the impact on the fed accounts or amounts for managing cash. In the first quarter, we had average cash balances of about $39.6 billion. That includes funds held at commercial banks as most funds held at the fed. In Q2, they went down to about $32.2 million. So they were down on average $7.4 billion versus Q1. The main driver for the lower cash balances is that the U.S. Treasury has been increasing net issuance of current refills, which had pushed yields higher and made the key bills more attractive than the returns that could be held holding cash. So for example, a 1-month treasury key Bill yield a neighborhood of about 190 basis points. So that reduction in the overall average balances has reduced our take from managing the cash for about $28 million in the first quarter to about $25 billion in the second quarter. So that should give you some color as to what occurred there. In terms of the audit findings. In the second quarter, audit findings were minimal. We had about little less than $2 million in audit findings in the second quarter impacting our market data. I think, what Bryan said is the most important, and that is, "Bringing that audit function in-house has allowed us to insure that there is compliance with our agreements, which has in turn gave us a more confidence terms of the numbers that are being reported, which obviously impacted the go forward amount that we bill our associated with market data." So some very positive from a go-forward perspective with audits.

We have a different rate associated with the OTC, the OTC, which is the fed effective rate less 10 basis points, which is about 181 basis points correctly going to our customers.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. this is Sean Tully. So you know, the Eurodollar futures and options have been very, very well this year, right? We continue to see growth and open interest, growth in volumes and a very strong performance there. So we're very excited about that. In t
componenttext: Yes. this is Sean Tully. So you know, the Eurodollar futures and options have been very, very well this year, right? We continue to see growth and open interest, growth in volumes and a very strong performance there. So we're very excited about that. In terms of sulfur, as you know, we've been one of the industry leaders, now flat for years in terms of the new rate. We're working very closely with the alternative reference rate in the entire industry. And we lost, as you know , the sulfur futures back in May. The uptake so far has been good. We've had more than 60 participants . We have more than 21,000 contracts in open interest , and we're seeing only about 3,000 contracts a day, but that's normal for a new contract. People are using our functionality in terms of economy spreads that we built between our hedge fund features and our silver futures and our overall features and our sulfur futures. We continue to market. We had a number of marketing events, actually almost one-week l one a week in the last 3 weeks, and they are very well attended. Yesterday we held a webinar on sulfur in terms of futures as well as the interest rates being for sulfur. And we had more than 400 participants. In terms of the interest rates of ops, we do plan on launching sulfur based interest rates while clearing in September, and we're very excited about that as well. So we're looking forward to it. The next step for the industry is really to see issuance from corporate issuers. And we do have an announcement from one of the government agencies yesterday that they are going to begin issuing software-based floaters soon. So that should help the market to develop your.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: We expect the LIBOR to remain in the Eurodollar complex for a long time. So as you know, right, the FCA has gotten the agreement from the panel banks to continue to post until the end of 2021. So we've got a long time for that transition to occur, but we
componenttext: We expect the LIBOR to remain in the Eurodollar complex for a long time. So as you know, right, the FCA has gotten the agreement from the panel banks to continue to post until the end of 2021. So we've got a long time for that transition to occur, but we do expect sulfur to grow at an alternative rate to LIBOR. And as issuance begins to develop, there'll be more need to hedge, more need to trade, and we expect to see much more volumes. So again, we continue to see very good growth in our Eurodollar futures in terms of volumes and open interest and we are the natural home for those o complex relative to being the lowest cost in terms of transacting with our intercommodity spreads between Eurodollars with a LIBOR based product that exists in the market price as well as the huge open interest that we have in our industry complex across hedge funds, Eurodollars, treasuries it allows the market place to be optimal kind of post rate margin in capital efficiencies. So we are the natural home. We are excited about it. We see the 2 different rates coexisting for a long time.

It's about 30 -- between $30 billion and $31 billion on average in terms of total cash balances here at CME Group through the first few weeks of July. In terms of whether or not the cash balances returned historical levels, really, it's up to the customers. There are many factors that impact the decisions, including, what collateral the customers have. The risk and closures at the closing house and the investments are a key factor in terms of whether or not the customers use cash or an alternative. As we've mentioned previously in many of these calls, there are alternatives investment vehicles for the customers to put their funds to work.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: All right. Thank you for the clarity. Just one follow up for me. Maybe a question for Derek on the other markets announced a future contract deliverable in Houston. Just wanted to hear your thoughts on the dynamics here and whether you've been hearing from customers that there is demand for a Houston-based oil contract? I know you offer some spread contracts today, but I'd love to hear some updated thoughts and strategy.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kyle. it's Derek. Thanks for your question. Yes. We're actually very excited about Houston as a marker. As you mentioned, we actually already launched the Houston crude oil contract back in Feb of '16 both an outright contract and a spread contract b
componenttext: Yes, Kyle. it's Derek. Thanks for your question. Yes. We're actually very excited about Houston as a marker. As you mentioned, we actually already launched the Houston crude oil contract back in Feb of '16 both an outright contract and a spread contract back to our WTI contract. We're actually quite happy with the growth of the contract that's trading between 3 million and 4 million barrels a day, and I actually continue to accept open interest records where we've seen about 145 million 150 million  barrels worth of open interest right now sitting at the Houston point. So actually pleased at the performance so far, and we think it's a high compliment for cushion contract. We recently set that up. We actually launched an outright and a spread contract at the same time, and what the market has adopted is actually the spread contract back to WTI. So the market's very happy with the deep liquidity and the WTI contract on Globex. The cash-owned spread contract back in Houston is providing exactly what the market wants, which is a cash equivalent of the barrel delivered to the coast. So we're excited about the opportunity. We think it's actually validation of what we did two years ago and the market's got the best of all worlds, which is deep liquid markets in the WTI and Globex and the utility to cash all of that spread out to Houston with barrels that hit the water.

componenttextpreview: So our electronic officers trade is about 64% of our total year-to-date so far, this year . That's up from 59% from last year. The biggest gains there are with interest rates going from 45% to 51%. Energy and metals each going up 5% as well. So we're cont
componenttext: So our electronic officers trade is about 64% of our total year-to-date so far, this year . That's up from 59% from last year. The biggest gains there are with interest rates going from 45% to 51%. Energy and metals each going up 5% as well. So we're continued to make investments, making it easier for customers to trade complex spread options on the box electronically. We are seeing the energy options at the one place where we're seeing a down drop five or six. Asset classes are up energy options right now. We're seeing record low -- back at record low relatively levels in net gas options. And we're seeing a pull back there. Strong healthy growth across the board at the other 5 asset classes. It's been a return to lower levels of volatility in 3 of our asset classes. And we're starting to see some seasonal dip back down in Q2 and some of the volatility level. So with that, we're seeing good strong growth across most of the franchise. Net gas option's the one outlier. WTI options are flattish with net gas down a bit. So I can hand it over to Sean for some of the details on the financial side.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: On seven on the financial side, I'll break it up into 2 pieces. I'll talk about the Eurodollar options, and then the long dated or the treasury options. In terms of the Eurodollar options, as you know, over the last four or five years, we've seen enormous
componenttext: On seven on the financial side, I'll break it up into 2 pieces. I'll talk about the Eurodollar options, and then the long dated or the treasury options. In terms of the Eurodollar options, as you know, over the last four or five years, we've seen enormous growth. So the comps related to last year are very, very difficult. If you look at our Eurodollar options complex doing more than 1.5 million contracts a day. So with the massive growth that we've seen and a little bit tougher growth as fast as it happened, but still, the Eurodollar options up about 3.8% year-over-year. On the other hand, our treasury option's doing much, much better at about 27% over year -- year-over-year. And basically, in line or slightly ahead of our future's complex. So I think, on the Eurodollar option size, specifically a tough comp.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And I think that what we're most excited about is we're trying to do the electronification and globalizing our businesses is our non-U.S. options growth year-to-date is up 19%. We're seeing outpaced volumes. Europe is up 19%, Asian and U.S. are up 13% Tha
componenttext: And I think that what we're most excited about is we're trying to do the electronification and globalizing our businesses is our non-U.S. options growth year-to-date is up 19%. We're seeing outpaced volumes. Europe is up 19%, Asian and U.S. are up 13% That a function of the growth investment in making in our infrastructure. We will to put complex spreads on the box has allowed us to capture net new clients traded electronically in their time zones. So we're excited about the growth and the trajectory in the options business overall, and again, the theme here is we are globalizing the business and increasing participation from outside of the U.S.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: One last thing I might add is, I should should've mentioned it earlier, we are innovating and continue to innovate. So we did launch a fifth quarterly curve option on our Eurodollar earlier this year. We also recently launched a new term mid curve options
componenttext: One last thing I might add is, I should should've mentioned it earlier, we are innovating and continue to innovate. So we did launch a fifth quarterly curve option on our Eurodollar earlier this year. We also recently launched a new term mid curve options. So that allows you to take very short-term one, two, three month options on our wides or fund for 4 contracts. So those -- even though they're very recently launched, we've traded well over 400,000 contracts. So we continue to innovate. We continue to see growth but tougher comps.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: So Rick, I hope that answers your question. But I think you got a good flavor, so a little bit tougher comps on the financial side, and a little bit of cyclical and just ebbs and flows as it relates to the gas side of the business. So all-in-all, a healthy, healthy complex.

componenttext: Go ahead, Bryan.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: You know, Rich, we do track this very closely, and I can just say that our subscriber counts have maintained a very stable level over the last several months since the price increase took effect. What I think is more interesting and more indicative is we'
componenttext: You know, Rich, we do track this very closely, and I can just say that our subscriber counts have maintained a very stable level over the last several months since the price increase took effect. What I think is more interesting and more indicative is we've seen a deceleration, actually, in the banking sector, which was an area where we were seeing a lot of attrition in past years. I think a lot of that is tied to the audit function, again, that we've been performing as we're in the field and we're building up those relationships, we're seeing a correction in behavior in the reporting of the screen count. So we're going to look at this, obviously, very closely, and in terms of audits as well, that's a lumpy area. I mentioned what we're more interested in is making sure that we have correct behavior, and that's reflecting itself in these numbers.

componenttext: Got it. Got it. I guess, last thing is, Terry, a prominent, publicly traded company out there has talked about, let's say, exploring the strategic alternatives for its post-trade services business. This service basically wraps trades, and then, they legally wrap it, and then, they report the trades to exchanges clearing houses -- I'm sure you're well aware of this, sir. I guess, the question is how interested are you in these type post-trade services?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: You know, from our standpoint right now, as I said earlier, the shareholder completed the integration process underway. You know, waiting for go ahead and approve both in the U.S. and in Europe, the U.K. Until we get that done, our focus is on and nothing else right now. And that's the way our strategy is peer so I really don't want to comment any further for that. We have to look at the post-trade services as we integrate any ex-business, but we can't do that until we close. So that's the only answer I could possibly give on that.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: The growth in Asia has always been very good. Year, we've seen stock market in China correct economic growth in that part of the world seems to be slowing but obviously still quite good. My question is, I guess, is there a risk to those volumes, do you think, if the economic situation in China gets worse, or do you feel like the volumes you're getting over there -- from over there are going to be pretty sticky?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: This is Bryan. I'll start. We really do feel that the volumes that we've been able to generate are going to continue to perform as well as it's been in the last few quarters. And it's really attributable to the outreach and the targeted planning across ea
componenttext: This is Bryan. I'll start. We really do feel that the volumes that we've been able to generate are going to continue to perform as well as it's been in the last few quarters. And it's really attributable to the outreach and the targeted planning across each of these countries. China, those represent a significant portion of our Asia-Pacific revenue. So I think it's important as well to keep in mind that we target our efforts across a multitude of countries. We're able to look at, for example, the top-tier countries within Asia-Pacific we have plans in which we do outreach across the product sectors and the client sectors , and those numbers are continuing to bear fruit.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: I think if you jump on the product-specific side, what we're actually seeing is where we have structural changes that provide unique opportunities for us to serve us a client base that is now open to us with structural changes like the energy markets, WTI
componenttext: I think if you jump on the product-specific side, what we're actually seeing is where we have structural changes that provide unique opportunities for us to serve us a client base that is now open to us with structural changes like the energy markets, WTI is now a waterborne global benchmark. So when you look at the growth in our business in just volumes alone, or Asian business is up 43%, and a last piece of that is  the energy business that we're pushing out in terms of WTI utilization. So part of this is , yes, tied to economic cycles, but we're paid to make sure that we can build franchises and portfolios that are going to thrive whether regardless of the shape of the yield curve, volatility curve or industrial cycles. What we are seeing is when products become more relevant to our global participants market in the best position to make sure that we're addressing that opportunity and that growth. So we're happy about the product selection. As Bryan said, we've put a lot of effort into training, education and the ability to access our markets through intermediaries. And that's showing through in some of the strong growth -- 43% revenue growth in our energy's franchise in China, for example. So we think the product set and the client mix are coming together, and we think that that's -- a structural shift is positive for us in the long-term.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: It is really difficult to say is, Derek, this outline about any specific part of anyone's economic growth and around the world, but I will tell you spend is the sales effort that we're putting in place globally. Historically, CME has never been much of a
componenttext: It is really difficult to say is, Derek, this outline about any specific part of anyone's economic growth and around the world, but I will tell you spend is the sales effort that we're putting in place globally. Historically, CME has never been much of a sales organization. We have bolstered this sales organization. We have got new initiatives globally to give new clients, that we believe are completely untapped and never used our markets that will be able to use our markets, so we're excited by that. The infrastructure that we're putting in different parts of Asia such as market regulation are the things that make your people really understand our markets. So we're sending people over there to, again, educate and make sure people understand what the U.S. market place is all about, and we're finding quite an excitement, and I do believe that the client base is really untapped. So even though there could be economic downturns, I think we have an opportunity to go after additional subsets of clients throughout the Asian community.

componenttext: This is actually Sameer on for Michael. Just a quick question on the expense guidance and the second half expenses. Usually, you would expect expenses to grow faster in the back half of the year, but given the unchanged guidance, it kind of seems that the second half would only grow around 2% to 3% year-over-year. So I just want to make up and details on maybe would expenses you might have put forward instead of first half. I think you guys called out compensation and bonuses. And maybe, what other segments you might hold expenses back in.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sameer, thanks for the question. Let's put this into perspective here for the first half of the year. So compensation, as you indicated, is our largest growth in terms of expenses. It's up about $28 million the first half of this year versus first half of
componenttext:
Sameer, thanks for the question. Let's put this into perspective here for the first half of the year. So compensation, as you indicated, is our largest growth in terms of expenses. It's up about $28 million the first half of this year versus first half of last year. 60% of the increase in the compensation line is incentive comps that this bonus and stock-based compensation. The balance is in bank conversation is because of the increases. We did have some increase in headcount. So if you exclude incentive-based compensation, our total adjusted expenses grew only 1.5% for the quarter, and on a year-to-date basis, adjusted expenses were flat with last year if you exclude incentive-based compensation. 
So looking into the second half of the year, going forward, I would expect the pattern of our spend remain similar with the fourth quarter heavier than the first quarter, but I would expect the fourth quarter to be less than 3% growth compared to last year. And so what you're seeing is for the first half of the year, we've been able to offset our compensation, incentive compensation growth, through really a great expense management across the entire organization and in going into second half of the year, I expect professional services and other expenses and marketing to be lower, which will still allow us to achieve our targeted expense guidance of about 3%.

Good day, and welcome to the CME Group Second Quarter 2018 Earnings Call. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. John Peschier. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us today. I'm going to start with the safe harbor language, then I will turn it over to Terry and John for brief remarks followed by questions. Other members of our management team will also participate in the Q
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you all for joining us today. I'm going to start with the safe harbor language, then I will turn it over to Terry and John for brief remarks followed by questions. Other members of our management team will also participate in the Q&A. 
Statements made on this call and in the slides on our website that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. These statements are not guarantees of future performance. They involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual outcomes and results may differ materially from what is expressed or implied in any statements. More detailed information about factors that may affect our performance can be found in our filings with the SEC, which are on our website. Also, on the last page of the earnings release, you will see a reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Terry.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And thank you -- as John said, thank you for joining us today. We appreciate your interest in CME group. I hope you got a chance to read through the Q2 earnings commentary that we provided earlier this morning. We had a very strong second quart
componenttext:
Thank you. And thank you -- as John said, thank you for joining us today. We appreciate your interest in CME group. I hope you got a chance to read through the Q2 earnings commentary that we provided earlier this morning. We had a very strong second quarter. We had record volume quarter in our agricultural product line and 4 additional asset classes grew double digits. 
Average daily volume was up 12% to more than 18 million contracts per day in Q2, following the record volumes in Q1. We reached a peak trading day of more than 50 million contracts on May 29. 
At the end of the first quarter, we announced the transaction with the NEX Group. As you know, the first order of business was the NEX shareholder approval, which was completed on May 19. We have begun our high-level integration planning process and are working closely with the teams of NEX. 
We continue to target a closing in the second half of this year. Global markets trading activity has slowed down during the month of July. July is, historically, one of the slower months of the year. Total ADV month-to-date at CME is down roughly 5%. But during this period 3 of our product areas have actually grown while the other 3 are down. 
When you add in the uncertainty of geopolitical issues and lower volatility, which we are seeing on top of a traditionally slow month, the 5% down isn't a surprise to me. As we all know, there are always ebbs and flows this time of year. It is worth noting that our open interest, as of this morning, is roughly 123 million contracts, which is up 10%, versus this point a year ago and has built nicely during the month of July. In addition, large open interest holder data across the 6 product areas remains very strong, and to me this is a better measurement. 
With that, I'm going to turn it over to John to make a few financial highlights and we'll get into your questions. John?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Terry. Revenue is up 15% this quarter, driven by higher transaction fee revenue, which was up 14%. We saw positive product mix pushing the total RBC higher to $0.757 during the quarter. Market data rose 18% primarily driven by the screen fee
componenttext:
Thank you, Terry. Revenue is up 15% this quarter, driven by higher transaction fee revenue, which was up 14%. We saw positive product mix pushing the total RBC higher to $0.757 during the quarter. 
Market data rose 18% primarily driven by the screen fee increase, which went into effect in April. By maintaining our expense discipline, we delivered adjusted operating margins similar to our record first quarter of this year. On an adjusted basis, total nonoperating income increased 37% from $29 million in Q2 last year to $40 million during the second quarter this year, driven primarily by the performance of our joint venture with S&P and the earnings and cash held at the clearing house. However, sequentially, we saw a lower average cash balances held at that clearing house by participants in the second quarter, as customers rotated into treasuries, which offered a higher yield in holding cash. 
The net amount earned through managing cash was up 18% compared to Q2 of 2017, but was down from Q1. With strong revenue growth and careful expense management, adjusted net income and EPS both grew over 40% during the quarter. 
With that short summary, we'd like to open up the call for your questions, and we'll start now.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: I guess, John, my first question is on market data. You highlighted in the prepared remarks about attrition as a result of the price increase. I guess, can you help us think about what historically that's been. And maybe how to think about growth in that line item for the remainder of this year?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Dan. We don't break out the components of our market data revenue. As you can see from our 20% sequential increase in revenue, the majority of the revenue comes from real-time fees. And was impacted by our price increase that went into effect
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Dan. We don't break out the components of our market data revenue. As you can see from our 20% sequential increase in revenue, the majority of the revenue comes from real-time fees. And was impacted by our price increase that went into effect in April. It's early to access the impacts of attrition. The team has done a good job of telegraphing the increase, bringing the audit function in-house has helped ensure compliance with our agreement and has helped mitigate those impacts. The team continues to work to soften any impact of the attrition. However, historically, as you can see from the times we've done price increases that there is some rationalization that occurs. So over to Bryan to comment on what he's hearing from customers.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Quite frankly, this was a key period for the introduction of that FD increase. And as John alluded to, the attrition rates are very stable. We didn't see a sizable shift based on what we've experienced in the past, which is positive news to us. I think wh
componenttext: Quite frankly, this was a key period for the introduction of that FD increase. And as John alluded to, the attrition rates are very stable. We didn't see a sizable shift based on what we've experienced in the past, which is positive news to us. I think what's very important to note is the effects of the audits that we have been conducting. In fact, what we are seeing is increased compliance, we're seeing more subscribers coming in to play as a result of those audits that were correcting wrong behavior, which is a positive. Also, a notable observation is significant increase in subscriber usage in the APAC region, which again, is another positive.

Well, can you just speak specifically as to what has changed structurally in those regions to drive growth? Have you targeted a new customer segment? Is it regulatory driven? I'm just trying to get a little bit more meat behind the -- what are very good numbers.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: I mean, first of all, as you know that our international average daily volume now is up 14% year-on-year to $4.4 million of our overall contract volume, it's very positive from our perspective. We've seen a 30% increase in activity in Asia, we're averagin
componenttext: I mean, first of all, as you know that our international average daily volume now is up 14% year-on-year to $4.4 million of our overall contract volume, it's very positive from our perspective. We've seen a 30% increase in activity in Asia, we're averaging close to 900,000 contracts today coming out of Asia. We're getting about 3.4 million average EMEA. You know really, this has been a story of investment and focused activities from sales and marketing and having the people on the ground as we've represented in the past. You heard me speak about country-specific planning and being able to target our focus across countries within each of these regions. And just to highlight, our customer segment year-on-year growth throughout international was led by the asset managers, up 42%. Commercials were up 35%. Banks were up 23%. Retail, nice growth, up 23%. Our overall nonmember growth was up 60% year-on-year in international.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And Chris, let me just add to what Bryan said, you mentioned regulatory, we don't think that's always a sustainable way to look at future growth. But I will tell you that when there is regulatory uncertainties, people migrate to where the certainty is at.
componenttext: And Chris, let me just add to what Bryan said, you mentioned regulatory, we don't think that's always a sustainable way to look at future growth. But I will tell you that when there is regulatory uncertainties, people migrate to where the certainty is at. In the United States where this Dodd-Frank act has already been passed and implemented many years ago and people understanding what the rules are, whether they like them or not is a different topic for discussion. But the point is, it's been done. And when you look at some of the European regions, obviously, they're not there yet. So that regulatory uncertainty does breathe less for volume there but it [indiscernible] brings [ it ] here to the states.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: The other point I would want to note is our focus on growing the volume during the regional hours. This is a story that we've been telling all of you for many, many quarters now. During Q2 2018, we saw a 34% increase in our activity during European tradin
componenttext: The other point I would want to note is our focus on growing the volume during the regional hours. This is a story that we've been telling all of you for many, many quarters now. During Q2 2018, we saw a 34% increase in our activity during European trading hours. 45% during Asian trading hours. So if you look and I know you have those dependencies, if you look at the overall volume that's occurring during their regional hours, a substantial portion of these activities are occurring during their delaying hours, it's very important to the growth story.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Great. One quick follow-up question. I -- Terry, you mentioned volumes have slowed in July, I do agree that is somewhat seasonal. The one that's a little surprising is just the ag volume, it seems even weaker than one would expect. Curious if the tariffs
componenttext: Great. One quick follow-up question. I -- Terry, you mentioned volumes have slowed in July, I do agree that is somewhat seasonal. The one that's a little surprising is just the ag volume, it seems even weaker than one would expect. Curious if the tariffs and things like that are having any impact? Or maybe any color on your end as to why you think volumes are slow -- really slow there?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Chris, and I'm going to let Derek go ahead and talk little bit about the ag complex, he heads that up. And then I'll give a small opinion after he's done it. Derek, go ahead and talk about it.
componenttext: Chris, and I'm going to let Derek go ahead and talk little bit about the ag complex, he heads that up. And then I'll give a small opinion after he's done it. Derek, go ahead and talk about it.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hi, Chris, and it's Derek. And we actually had a series of records over the course of the -- this year in Q2. We had a monthly record -- total volume went record open insurance record [ quarter ] on track for the -- for -- continue to push those dire
componenttext: Yes. Hi, Chris, and it's Derek. And we actually had a series of records over the course of the -- this year in Q2. We had a monthly record -- total volume went record open insurance record [ quarter ] on track for the -- for -- continue to push those directions. What we're also seeing is record large open interest holders in our market. And what's important, tying back the question that Bryan just answered is our non-U.S. growth story, with Trump announcing tariffs that are coming on board that has created a significant concern about price risk. That drove a lot of the volume into participation in our contracts. This is very much a risk on environment as represented by the record volume and record open interest and large open interest holders. We're also seeing on the day that we saw record volumes overall in the complex back in June. Most important, we saw record levels of participation from non-U.S. participants. So as regulatory concerns come on board relative to tariffs or not, we're actually seeing people pile in. For example, with the announcement yesterday. Trump and Juncker meeting, that had a very positive impact. We've seeing our ag volumes overnight roughly come in at twice the amount. As of 7 o'clock this morning, we had about 220,000 contracts in our ag contracts. We typically see a slowdown going into the 7 months of Q3. We're coming from record highs in Q1 and Q2, and our ag volume has also set a record over the course of Q2. So we're seeing some seasonal basis of slowdown. But right now we're, as Terry mentioned before, starting from record levels of open insurance and global participation. So I think we feel good about what the balance of the year is going to bring. And we've seen immediate positive impact in our volumes based on the questions that have risen so far.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And I think -- just to add to that question and I think that the real story here is not so much on what the volumes are, because as Derek said, we are the benchmark pricing mechanism for the agriculture throughout the world. I think it's just the overall
componenttext: And I think -- just to add to that question and I think that the real story here is not so much on what the volumes are, because as Derek said, we are the benchmark pricing mechanism for the agriculture throughout the world. I think it's just the overall price that the impact on the regional farmers during the U.S. versus globally. So the difference between the Zoy and soybean prices -- U.S. soybean prices, that's really where most of the story is being told, but I do think that will be ironed out. Hence, when you saw, what Derek just referenced with, the conversations between Europe and the U.S., we're hopeful -- I'm hopeful for the U.S. environment that it will go the same way with Asia.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: Maybe just -- let me just start with a couple of clarifications. For John, the -- if you could talk about the net rate that you're earning on those clients, cash balances held at the clearing house,  and maybe that's the day we're down on a -- on an average basis since 3Q so far. Maybe if you could talk about that net rate earned after the June hikes. So the 3Q earning rate. And then just a clarification on the market data. I think you guys raised the pricing on April 15, if I'm correct on that. And to what extent audit fees impacted that market data number in Q2?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thank you, Bryan. I'll walk you through, kind of, the Fed accounts and what occurred this quarter, then I'll hit the market data question. So in terms of the impact on the Fed accounts or the -- amounts that we held for managing cash. In the first q
componenttext: Sure. Thank you, Bryan. I'll walk you through, kind of, the Fed accounts and what occurred this quarter, then I'll hit the market data question. So in terms of the impact on the Fed accounts or the -- amounts that we held for managing cash. In the first quarter, we had average cash balances of about $39.6 billion, that includes funds held at commercial banks as well as funds held at the Fed. In Q2, they went down to about $32.2 billion. So they were down on average $7.4 billion versus Q1. The main driver for the lower cash balances is that the U.S. Treasury has been increasing net issuance of treasury bills, which has pushed yields higher and made the key bills more attractive than the returns that could be held holding cash. So for example, 1-month treasury key bill yields a neighborhood of about 190 basis points. So that reduction in the overall average balances has reduced our take from managing the cash for about $28 million in the first quarter to about $25 million in the second quarter. So that should give you some color as to what occurred there. In terms of the audit findings. In the second quarter, audit findings were minimal. We had about little less than $2 million in audit findings in the second quarter impacting market data. I think, what Bryan said is the most important and that is, "Bringing that audit function in-house has allowed us to ensure that there's compliance with our agreements." Which has in turn gave us more confidence in terms of the numbers that are being reported, which obviously impacted going forward amount that we bill -- associated with market data. So some very positive from a go-forward perspective with audits.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Sean jumping in. So our Eurodollar futures and options have done very, very well this year, right? We continue to see growth in open interest, growth in volumes and a very strong performance there. So we're very excited about that. In terms o
componenttext: Yes, this is Sean jumping in. So our Eurodollar futures and options have done very, very well this year, right? We continue to see growth in open interest, growth in volumes and a very strong performance there. So we're very excited about that. In terms of SOFR, as you know, we've been one of the industry leaders, now flat 3 years in terms of the new rate. Working very closely with the alternative reference rate committee in the entire industry. And we lost, as you know, the SOFR future is back in May. The uptake so far has been good. We've had more than 60 participants, we have more than 21,000 contracts in open interest, and we're seeing only about 3,000 contracts a day, but that's normal for a new contract. People are using our functionality in terms of the intercommodity spreads that we built between our hedge fund futures and our SOFR futures have also -- Euro futures and our SOFR futures. So we're excited about it, we continue to market. We've had a number of marketing events, actually almost 1 a week in the last 3 weeks, and they are very well attended. Yesterday we held a webinar on SOFR in terms of the futures as well as interest rates swap clearing for SOFR, and we had more than 400 participants. In terms of the interest rate swaps, we do plan on launching SOFR-based interest rate swap clearing in September, and we're very excited about that as well. So we're looking forward to it. The next step for the industry is really to see issuance from corporate issuers. And we do have an announcement from one of the government agencies yesterday that they are going to begin issuing SOFR-based floaters soon. So that should help the marketplace to develop.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, that's right. Yes.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, that's right. Yes.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: We expect LIBOR to remain right in terms of Eurodollar complex for a long time. So as you know, right? The FCA has gotten agreement from the panel banks to continue to post until the end of 2021, right? So we've got a long time for that transition to occu
componenttext: We expect LIBOR to remain right in terms of Eurodollar complex for a long time. So as you know, right? The FCA has gotten agreement from the panel banks to continue to post until the end of 2021, right? So we've got a long time for that transition to occur. But we do expect SOFR to grow as an alternative rate to LIBOR. And as issuance begins to develop, there'll be more need to hedge, more need to trade, and we expect to see much more volumes. So again, we continue to see very good growth in our Eurodollar futures in terms of volumes and open interest. And we are the natural home for the SOFR complex relative to being the lowest cost in terms of transacting with our intercommodity spreads between Eurodollars with a LIBOR-based product that exists in the marketplace as well as the huge open interest that we have in our industry complex across Fed funds, Eurodollars and treasuries, which allow the marketplace the optimal kind of post-trade margin in capital efficiencies. So we are the natural home. We are excited about it. We see the 2 different rates coexisting for a long time.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: Yes. So in terms of -- kind of, in terms of current balances, they are roughly in line with the -- with last quarter. It's about 30 -- between $30 billion and $31 billion on average in terms of total cash balances here at CME Group through the first few weeks of July. In terms of whether or not the cash balance has returned to historical levels, really, it's up to the customers. And there are many factors that impact their decisions, including, what collateral the customers has, the risks, exposures at the clearing house and the yield on alternative investments all play a factor in terms of whether or not the customers use cash or an alternative. As we've mentioned previously in many of these calls, there are alternatives investment vehicles for the customers to put their funds to work.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you for the clarity. And just one follow up from me. Maybe a question for Derek on the oil markets, a competitor of your recently announced a crude oil futures contract deliverable in Houston. Just wanted to hear your thoughts on the dyna
componenttext: All right. Thank you for the clarity. And just one follow up from me. Maybe a question for Derek on the oil markets, a competitor of your recently announced a crude oil futures contract deliverable in Houston. Just wanted to hear your thoughts on the dynamics here and whether you've been hearing from customers that there's demand for a Houston-based oil contract? I know you offer some spread contracts today, but just love to hear some updated thoughts and strategy.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kyle, it's Derek. Thanks for your question. Yes, we're actually very excited about Houston as a marker. As you mentioned, we actually already launched the Houston crude oil contract back in Feb of '16, both an outright contract and a spread contract
componenttext: Yes, Kyle, it's Derek. Thanks for your question. Yes, we're actually very excited about Houston as a marker. As you mentioned, we actually already launched the Houston crude oil contract back in Feb of '16, both an outright contract and a spread contract back to our WTI contract. We're actually very happy with the growth of the contract that's trading between 3 million and 4 million barrels a day. And I actually continue to set open interest records where we've seen about 145 million to 150 million barrels worth of open interest right now sitting at the Houston point. So we're actually pleased with the performance so far, and we think it's a high compliment for the Cushing contract. The reason we set that up, we actually launched an outright and a spread contract at the same time, we're letting the market choose whichever they wanted adopt and what the market has adopted is actually the spread contract back to WTI. So the market's very happy with the deep liquidity and the WTI contract on Globex. The cash-owned spread contract back in Houston is providing exactly what the market wants, which is a cash equivalent of the barrel delivered to the coast. So we're excited about the opportunity. We think it's actually validation of what we did 2 years ago and the market's got the best of all worlds, which is deep liquid markets in the WTI and Globex and then the ability to cash all of that spread out to Houston with barrels that hit the water.

componenttextpreview: Okay. So our electronic officers traded about 64% of our total year-to-date so far this year. That's up from 59% last year. The biggest gains there are with interest rates going from 45% to 51%. Energy and metals each going up 5% as well. So we continue t
componenttext: Okay. So our electronic officers traded about 64% of our total year-to-date so far this year. That's up from 59% last year. The biggest gains there are with interest rates going from 45% to 51%. Energy and metals each going up 5% as well. So we continue to make investments, make it easier for customers to trade complex spread options on the box electronically. We are seeing that energy options are the one place where we've seeing a down drop, 5 of 6 asset classes are up energy options right now. We're seeing record low -- back at record low volatility levels in net gas options, we're seeing a pull back there. Strong healthy growth across the board, the other 5 asset classes. It's then -- it returned to lower levels of volatility in 3 of our asset classes. And we're starting to see some seasonal dip back down in Q2 and some of the volatility level. So with that, we're seeing good strong growth across most of the franchise. Nat gas options the one outlier. WTI options are flattish with nat gas down a bit. So I can hand it over to Sean on some of the details on the financial side.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the financial side, I'd -- I'll break it up into 2 pieces. I'll talk about the Eurodollar options and then the long-dated or the treasury options. In terms of the Eurodollar options, as you know, over the last 4 or 5 years, we've seen enormous gro
componenttext: Yes. On the financial side, I'd -- I'll break it up into 2 pieces. I'll talk about the Eurodollar options and then the long-dated or the treasury options. In terms of the Eurodollar options, as you know, over the last 4 or 5 years, we've seen enormous growth. So the comps relative to last year are very, very difficult. If you look at our Eurodollar options complex doing more than 1.5 million contracts a day. So with the massive growth that we've seen and a little bit tougher growth very -- as fast as we happened. But still, the Eurodollar options up about 3.8% year-over-year. On the other hand, our treasury options doing much, much better at up 27% over year -- year-over-year. And basically, in line or slightly ahead of our futures complex. So I think, on the Eurodollar option size, specifically, a tough comp.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: And I think that what we're most excited about is we're planning a theme of electronification and globalizing our businesses, as our non-U.S. options growth year-to-date is up 19%. We're seeing outpaced volumes. Europe is up 19%, Asian and U.S. are up 13%
componenttext: And I think that what we're most excited about is we're planning a theme of electronification and globalizing our businesses, as our non-U.S. options growth year-to-date is up 19%. We're seeing outpaced volumes. Europe is up 19%, Asian and U.S. are up 13%, both -- that fit -- the reflection of the growth investment we're making in our infrastructure and the ability to put complex spreads on the boxes is allowing us to capture net new clients traded electronically in their time zones. So we're excited about the growth and the trajectory, the options business overall. And again, the theme here is we are globalizing the business and increasing participation from outside of the U.S.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: One last thing I might add is, I should've mentioned it earlier. We are innovating, we continue to innovate. So we continue to innovate. We continue to see growth, but tougher comps.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Rich, we're -- we do track this very closely, and I can just say that our subscriber counts have maintained a very stable level over these last several months since the price increase took effect. What I think is more interesting and more indicative is we
componenttext: Rich, we're -- we do track this very closely, and I can just say that our subscriber counts have maintained a very stable level over these last several months since the price increase took effect. What I think is more interesting and more indicative is we've seen a deceleration, actually, in the banking sector, which was an area where we were seeing a lot of attrition in past years. I think a lot of that is tied to the audit function, again, that we've been performing as we're in the field and we're building up those relationships, we're seeing a correction in behavior in the reporting of the screen count. So we're going to look at this, obviously, very closely. And in terms of audits as well, that's a lumpy area, I mentioned. What we're more interested in is making sure that we have correct behavior. And that's reflecting itself in these numbers.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: Got it. Got it. I guess, last thing is, Terry, a prominent publicly traded company out there has talked about, let's say, exploring strategic alternatives for its post-trade services business. This service basically wraps trades and then, they legally wrap it and then they report the trades to exchanges clearing houses, I'm sure you're well aware of this, sir. I guess, the question is how interested are you in these type post-trade services?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Rich, from our standpoint, right now I would -- just as I said earlier, the announcement of NEX, the shareholder vote of NEX being completed, the integration process underway. Waiting for the authorities to go ahead and approve both in the U.S. and in Eur
componenttext: Rich, from our standpoint, right now I would -- just as I said earlier, the announcement of NEX, the shareholder vote of NEX being completed, the integration process underway. Waiting for the authorities to go ahead and approve both in the U.S. and in Europe and U.K. Until we get that done, our focus is on NEX and nothing else right now. And that's the way our strategy is, so I really don't want to comment any further because for that we have to look at post-trade services as we start to integrate the NEX business, but we can't do that until we close. So that's the only answer I could possibly give on that.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: This is Bryan. I'll start. We really do feel that the volumes that we've been able to generate are going to continue to perform as well as then -- these last few quarters. And it's really attributable to the outreach and the targeted planning across each
componenttext: This is Bryan. I'll start. We really do feel that the volumes that we've been able to generate are going to continue to perform as well as then -- these last few quarters. And it's really attributable to the outreach and the targeted planning across each of these countries. China, does represent a significant portion of our Asia Pacific revenue. So I think it's important as well to keep in mind that we target our efforts across a multitude of countries. We're able to look at, for example, the top-10 countries, within Asia Pacific we have plans in which we do outreach across the product sectors and the client sectors, and those numbers are continuing to bear fruit.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: I think if you jump in on the product-specific side, we're actually seeing is where we have structural changes that provide unique opportunities for us to service a client base that is now open to us with structural changes, like the energy market. WTI is
componenttext: I think if you jump in on the product-specific side, we're actually seeing is where we have structural changes that provide unique opportunities for us to service a client base that is now open to us with structural changes, like the energy market. WTI is now a waterborne global benchmark. So when you look at the growth in our business in just volumes alone, our Asian business is up 43% and a large piece of that is the energy business that we're pushing out in terms of WTI utilization. So part of this is, yes, tied to economic cycles, but we're paid to make sure that we can build franchises and portfolios that are going to thrive whether regardless of the shape of the yield curve, volatility curve or industrial cycles. What we are seeing is when products become more relevant to global participants, we're in the best position to make sure that we're addressing that opportunity and that growth. So -- and so we're happy about the product selection, and to Bryan's point, we put a lot of effort into training, education and the ability to access our markets through intermediaries. And that's showing through in some of the strong growth, 43% revenue growth in our energy's franchise in China, for example. So we think product set and the client mix are coming together, and we think that that's -- a structural shift is positive for us in the long term.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: It is really difficult to say, as Derek just outlined, about any particular part of anyone's economic growth and around the world. But I will tell you -- and I touched on this but I don't mean to enough extent is the sales effort that we are putting in pl
componenttext: It is really difficult to say, as Derek just outlined, about any particular part of anyone's economic growth and around the world. But I will tell you -- and I touched on this but I don't mean to enough extent is the sales effort that we are putting in place globally. Historically, CME has never been much of a sales organization. We have bolstered this sales organization. We have got new initiatives globally to get new clients, that we believe are completely untapped, never used our markets that we'll be able to use our markets, so we're excited by that. The infrastructure that we're putting in different parts of Asia such as market regulations, other things that make sure people really understand our markets. So we're sending people over there to, again, educate and make sure people understand what the U.S. marketplace is all about. And we're finding quite an excitement, and I do believe that the client base is really untapped there. So even though there could be economic downturns, I think we have an opportunity to go after additional subsets of clients throughout the Asian community.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018

componenttext: This is actually Sameer Murukutla on for Michael. Just a quick question on the expense guidance and the second half expenses. Usually, you would expect expenses to grow faster in the back half of the year, but given the unchanged guidance, it kind of seems like the second half would only grow around 2% to 3% year-over-year. So I just want to make up some details on maybe what expenses you might have put forward instead of first half. I think you guys called out compensation and bonuses. And maybe, what other segments you might hold expenses back.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Sameer, thanks for the question. Yes, let's put this into perspective here for the first half of the year. So compensation, as you indicated, is our largest growth in terms of expenses. It's up about $28 million first half of this year versus first half o
componenttext:
Sameer, thanks for the question. Yes, let's put this into perspective here for the first half of the year. So compensation, as you indicated, is our largest growth in terms of expenses. It's up about $28 million first half of this year versus first half of last year. 60% of the increase in the compensation line is incentive comps so that is bonus and stock-based compensation. The balance is in bank conversation is primarily driven by cost of living increases. We did have some increase in headcount. So if you exclude incentive-based compensation, our total adjusted expenses grew only 1.5% for the quarter and on a year-to-date basis adjusted expenses were flat with last year if you exclude incentive-based compensation.
So looking into the second half of the year, so rolling it forward, I would expect the pattern of our spend to remain similar with the fourth quarter heavier than the first quarter. But I would expect the fourth quarter to be less than 3% growth compared to last year. And so what you're seeing is for the first half of the year, we've been able to offset our compensation -- incentive compensation growth, through really, I think, great expense management across the entire organization and rolling into second half of the year, I would expect professional services and other expenses and marketing to be lower, which will still allow us to achieve our targeted expense guidance of about 3%.

Good day, and welcome to the CME Group Second Quarter 2018 Earnings Call. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. John Peschier. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you all for joining us today. I'm going to start with the safe harbor language, then I will turn it over to Terry and John for brief remarks followed by questions. Other members of our management team will also participate in the Q
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you all for joining us today. I'm going to start with the safe harbor language, then I will turn it over to Terry and John for brief remarks followed by questions. Other members of our management team will also participate in the Q&A. 
Statements made on this call and in the slides on our website that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. These statements are not guarantees of future performance. They involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual outcomes and results may differ materially from what is expressed or implied in any statements. More detailed information about factors that may affect our performance can be found in our filings with the SEC, which are on our website. Also, on the last page of the earnings release, you will see a reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Terry.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And thank you -- as John said, thank you for joining us today. We appreciate your interest in CME group. I hope you got a chance to read through the Q2 earnings commentary that we provided earlier this morning. We had a very strong second quart
componenttext:
Thank you. And thank you -- as John said, thank you for joining us today. We appreciate your interest in CME group. I hope you got a chance to read through the Q2 earnings commentary that we provided earlier this morning. We had a very strong second quarter. We had a record volume quarter in our agricultural product line and 4 additional asset classes grew double digits. 
Average daily volume was up 12% to more than 18 million contracts per day in Q2, following the record volumes in Q1. We reached a peak trading day of more than 50 million contracts on May 29. 
At the end of the first quarter, we announced the transaction with the NEX Group. As you know, the first order of business was the NEX shareholder approval, which was completed on May 19. We have begun our high-level integration planning process and are working closely with the teams of NEX. 
We continue to target a closing in the second half of this year. Global markets trading activity has slowed down during the month of July. July is, historically, one of the slower months of the year. Total ADV month-to-date at CME is down roughly 5%. But during this period 3 of our product areas have actually grown while the other 3 are down. 
When you add in the uncertainty of geopolitical issues and lower volatility which we are seeing on top of a traditionally slow month, the 5% down isn't a surprise to me. As we all know, there are always ebbs and flows this time of year. It is worth noting that our open interest, as of this morning, is roughly 123 million contracts, which is up 10%, versus this point a year ago and has built nicely during the month of July. In addition, large open interest holder data across the 6 product areas remains very strong, and to me this is a better measurement. 
With that, I'm going to turn it over to John to make a few financial highlights and we'll get into your questions. John?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Terry. Revenue was up 15% this quarter, driven by higher transaction fee revenue, which was up 14%. We saw positive product mix pushing the total RPC higher to $0.757 during the quarter. Market data rose 18% primarily driven by the screen fee
componenttext:
Thank you, Terry. Revenue was up 15% this quarter, driven by higher transaction fee revenue, which was up 14%. We saw positive product mix pushing the total RPC higher to $0.757 during the quarter. 
Market data rose 18% primarily driven by the screen fee increase, which went into effect in April. By maintaining our expense discipline, we delivered adjusted operating margins similar to our record first quarter of this year. On an adjusted basis, total nonoperating income increased 37% from $29 million in Q2 last year to $40 million during the second quarter this year, driven primarily by the performance of our joint venture with S&P and the earnings on cash held at the clearing house. However, sequentially, we saw a lower average cash balances held at that clearing house by participants in the second quarter, as customers rotated into treasuries, which offered a higher yield than holding cash. 
The net amount earned through managing cash was up 18% compared to Q2 of 2017, but was down from Q1. With strong revenue growth and careful expense management, adjusted net income and EPS both grew over 40% during the quarter. 
With that short summary, we'd like to open up the call for your questions, and we'll start now.

I guess, can you help us think about what historically that's been. And maybe how to think about growth in that line item for the remainder of this year?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Dan. We don't break out the components of our market data revenue. As you can see from our 20% sequential increase in revenue, the majority of the revenue comes from realtime fees. And was impacted by our price increase that went into effect
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Dan. We don't break out the components of our market data revenue. As you can see from our 20% sequential increase in revenue, the majority of the revenue comes from realtime fees. And was impacted by our price increase that went into effect in April. It's early to assess the impacts of attrition. The team has done a good job of telegraphing the increase, bringing the audit function in-house has helped ensure compliance with our agreement and has helped mitigate those impacts. The team continues to work to soften any impact of the attrition. However, historically, as you can see from the times we've done price increases that there is some rationalization that occurs. I will turn it over to Bryan to comment on what he's hearing from customers.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2018 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2018
componenttextpreview: Quite frankly, this was a key period for the introduction of that [ FD ] increase. And as John alluded to, the attrition rates are very stable. We didn't see a sizable shift based on what we've experienced in the past, which is positive news to us. I thin
componenttext: Quite frankly, this was a key period for the introduction of that [ FD ] increase. And as John alluded to, the attrition rates are very stable. We didn't see a sizable shift based on what we've experienced in the past, which is positive news to us. I think what's very important to note is the effects of the audits that we have been conducting. Because what we are seeing is increased compliance, we're seeing more subscribers coming in to play as a result of those audits. So we are correcting wrong behavior, which is a positive. Also, a notable observation is significant increase in subscriber usage in the APAC region, which again, is another positive.
